Here are a few more suggestions about how to debunk election misinformation shared by your friends and family.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/wellness/2022/10/05/debunk-political-misinformation-advice/

Correcting misinformation can take time, and not everyone wants to be persuaded. But it's important to correct it when you can so everyone else in the group chat or reading the comments knows not to believe it and isn't discouraged from voting.
Ask who benefits if they don't vote. Remind them that their vote ALWAYS matters. Offer to help them find out where and when they can vote, or even to join them at the polls!

If a friend shares something that looks like misinformation, ask where they found it. Then redirect them to a reliable source, like http://IWillVote.com or your state board of elections. Be kind and keep it short, don't try to overwhelm them by sending multiple corrections.

Election Day is just 1 week away, and foreign actors are already ramping up their efforts to push misinformation to discourage you from voting.

Once it's pushed out, this type of misinfo is often shared person-to-person in texts or on social media. Here's how you can debunk it. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FgguSAsWYAIDRwc.jpg
